### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where is a paper notice likely to be left on a house? Choices:  A: front door B: conference C: classroom D: refrigerator E: suitcase<n>Output:		 For the house that has a front door, it most likely is B<n>The answer is B<n><n>Input:A table is sold on the street for 500 guilders. (Solution, page 2)<n>Output: The table is sold for 500 guilders.<n>Her price was 500.<n>The buyer was 500.<n>The seller was 500<n><n>Input:If the weather is warm in May, it is a sure sign of summer. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:The child pounded his mitt in excitement while enjoying his first game in the bleachers where? Choices:  A: football stadium B: laboratory C: baseball stadium D: pharmacy E: soccer game<n>Output:		B.<n>So it is most likely that he only hit his fist to the ball that hit the ground near his body while his head bounced off the back of the bleachers<n><n>Input:The total number of calories burned by a marathoner is given as 200kcal. For a person of normal weight and height, the burned calories is calculated as 2.5kcal which is 40% of the daily recommended amount. For a runner, the calories burned by the marathoner are calculated as 60% of daily recommended amount. Calculate the number of days in which the runner burned 600 calories per day.<n>Output:Calculate the number of days the runner burned 600 kcal per day<n>If the days are equal, the overall number of days is 2 in which the runner burned 200 kcal per day.<n>If the running is more than 2, the overall number of runs is 4 in which the runner burned 300 kcal per day.<n>Since the number of runs are equal, the sum total is 4 in which the total running was 300 kcal per day<n>If one runs 5, he burns 600 kcal per day<n><n>Input:Jack has a heart of stone. Since this is the fifth year that he has been an employee, Jack earns $3500 plus a 50% bonus.  Every year he goes on a trip with Jim and the other employees.  There were three years in which there was not a trip of this nature - four years in which there was a trip of this nature. If there are no more trips next year, Jack is guaranteed a job.  If there are more trips in the future, he will earn up to $500 dollars every time, more with more years in<n>Output:Calculating the number of days it took to reach this level of bonuses<n>If there are no trips in 2015, Jack can expect $50 bonus per year<n>If there are more trips in 2016, Jack will earn $80 bonuses a year<n>If there are additional trips in 2017 or 2018, then he will earn $150 bonuses per year<n>If there were no trips next year that year, then he can expect $200 bonus per year<n>If he has a job in 2019, by the time he reaches the fifth year of the bonus he will have earned over $600 bonus per year which will increase exponentially by his fifth year.<n>Calculating the number the bonuses that he will earn in any given year<n>If he earned $400 bonus this year, then his total income next year will be $600

Therefore, the total cost of ownership for an iPod is $150.  Total cost for a new iPod with its battery replaced and in good working condition is $250. Therefore the total cost of ownership in this case is $350.  The total cost to buy a new iPod with its charger and its battery replaced is $850. Therefore the total cost for the iPod is $950. How much of the time will the third group spend on other movements?<n>Output:The 3 groups lift weights until they are each at 400 pounds. Then when each group lifts the weights again to reach the goal weights, they are put on different exercises. The first group lifts until they are all at 400 pounds. The first group does the second group's exercises and the second group does the third groups' exercises until each group reaches the goals again. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What is a place that could have hundreds of sporting goods store? Choices:  A: buy athletic equipment B: city C: espn D: town E: jerseys<n>Output:		 A<n>A. The shopping mall<n>B. The department store<n>C. The soccer stores<n>D. The baseball stores<n>E. The basketball stores.<n><n>Input: James goes to a doctor's office.  Every four weeks he gets a physical exam. Every two years his doctor performs an eye exam. He is adjusting your medical history<n>C. He is increasing your health insurance premiums.<n>D. He is charging you more money for medical services.<n>E. He is charging you too little for medical service.<n><n>Input:<n>If you had the power of Attorney to spend $200 to buy a $200 television set, and if you could not be without television for four months, how much of that could you spend on television?<n>Output: 100%<n>But you could not get a TV set from the shopping mall; so you buy a set from the department store at a markup.<n>So you spend 300% of the $200 on the new TV set<n><n>input:<n>The cost of your home insurance is $2,400 for this year.  What would you expect the cost to be in a year if you moved to another state?<n>Output: 1/2<n>If you move to another state, you would get insurance for $4000.  But the replacement of your home would cost you $7,500.  So the replacement cost of the home would be $10,400*2*350/2=$12,050.<n>Input:<n>When Adam, James and Joe all bought the same television sets, total cost of ownership of all of those sets was $20,000.  The total cost of ownership of the TV equipment of all three men total was $150,000.<n>Input:<n>Jack has $200 a month to put into savings. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:People want to explore space, so what should they use to do it? Choices:  A: public place B: roadblock C: space shuttle D: hoverboard E: supermarket<n>Output:		 A: roadblock B: space shuttle C: Hoverboard D: supermarket<n>That is 2/3<n><n>Input: A man was walking to the store. He asked his wife to come to the store with him.  She refused.  Instead, she bought a loaf of bread and a glass of milk that her husband needed to get to the store.  How much did she spend to run to the store?<n>Output: A loaf of bread at a $40 per loaf cost $2.75. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. Choices:  A: see work B: shocked C: humor D: startled E: funny<n>Output:		When he touched the uncovered wire he shouldn't have felt like he should have gotten shocked.<n>Then they should be shocked or hurt<n><n>Input:In order for the earth to expand, an object must be pulled outward from the surface of the earth.<n>Output:If the earth pushes away from the ground by a force x it moves away and expels the object which then falls back down, then this falls back into the earth until the force x is equal to zero.<n>Therefore x=0.<n>Therefore x=10/10^3<n>Therefore x/10^3=40<n>Therefore x=40/10^3=12<n>Therefore x=12/10^3=24<n>Therefore x=12.<n>Therefore x = 12/10^3=150<n>Therefore x = 150/10^3=100<n><n>Input:When the sun rises in the west and sets in the east, it moves the earth at a rate of.0000001 second per second in the western direction and.000001 second per second in the eastern direction. What is the rate that it moves?<n>Output:If we keep measuring this rate over time, the earth will move at a rate of.00000001 second per second in each direction.<n>Therefore in a year the earth moves about.00000001 second per year in the west and.00000001 second per day in the east.<n>Therefore in a decade the earth moves about 80,000,000.0000001 seconds per day in each direction<n>Therefore in a century the earth will move approximately 15,000,000,000.00000001 seconds per day in each way.<n>Therefore the total time the earth moves every year is 100,000,000, 000.00000001 seconds.<n>Therefore the total hours the earth stays within the time zone (east or west) is 100,000, 000,000.00000001 days.<n>Therefore the total number of days the earth moves to the other side before it can move again is 100,000, 00.00000001 days.

If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:The turkey needed to be kept from spoiling, what is useful in this situation? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: fridge C: freezer D: oven E: bought at store<n>Output:		 Buying a second turkey is only useful if you are the only person on the planet who cooks  Thanksgiving.<n><n>Input: An 8-foot-8-inch watermelon was purchased at a produce stand.  Two days later, a 7-foot-3-inch watermelon of the same type was purchased at the same place.  What is the difference in price?<n>Output: The price of the 8-foot-8 watermelon was $0.  The price of the 7-foot-3 watermelon was $5.  They are identical.<n><n>Input:The number of people in the classroom who could not read simple sentences written in English without help was 4.  How many of them were unable to read the sentence written in Japanese that is in this puzzle?<n>Output: There were 4 who wrote an incomprehensible sentence.<n><n>Input:To calculate the value of a new phone, we have to look at the cost of two-year old cell phones, which cost $200 each.  What are the two cell phone models you would recommend?<n>Output: We recommend a $200 Samsung.  It is the latest and greatest.<n><n>Input:A group of eight people sat on an airplane.  There was a boy who was not allowed to get on the plane because he had a wet diaper.  He waited in the exit row, while the other eight people, who had a diaper, got on the plane.  What is the least possible number of people that can fit in one row?<n>Output: Eight is the least possible number. Two rows of seats would be the same as four. This means that there are 2*2*4*2*4 people in two rows, that will fit on one row. If six people get in one row, and two people get in the other, the six people in the other row will get a wet diaper more often than the two people in the first row.<n><n>input:If you had one dollar that you could spend every time anyone said "Oh, my God!" what would you buy? output:I'll buy a whole box of cookies at Dunkin Donuts. I've eaten too many already!
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:If I have to keep track of how much oxygen there is, where am I? Choices:  A: air B: water C: earth D: space shuttle E: tunnel<n>Output:		You are in an empty room.  Your room, at ground level, has 3 cubic meters of air.  At the top of the room you can hear the sounds of the rest of the floor and room below you.  On the floor below you, you can smell the dust and dirt of the rest of the room.  At the bottom, you can hear the sounds that are making their way toward you.<n>Output: You have to calculate the volume of air that you can breathe before you reach the top of the room.  Input:You have to find the volume of air that the rest of the room can breathe before reaching you.<n>Output:You have to calculate the volume that the rest of the floor can breathe before reaching you.

He runs all the way from his friend's house to the police station, so he can escape from them, before the cold is too strong. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. So in that case, each might taste more. I think most think A is better but I disagree as there will more ways tastes combine. I think people with E are more like A in flavor than D people who eat all sorts of tastes.

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What would release energy, but not mainly in your muscles? Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n>Output:		 if release energy by your muscles, you have used up all the energy released by the muscles you had been working on previously. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. Choices:  A: jigsaw puzzle B: chess game C: puzzle box D: jigsaw puzzel puxxle E: puxxle<n>Output:		 1 piece made from jigsaw puzzle = 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 2 B piece made from chess game = 1 + 1 + 2 + 2 = 3 C piece made from puxxle = 1 + 2 + 2 + 2 = 4 D piece made from puzzle box = 1 + 2 + 3 + 3 = 4 E piece made from puzzle puxxle = 2 + 3 + 3 + 2 = 5 P piece made from puxxxle = 1 + 3 + 3 + 3 = 5

What is the weight of the apples without the seeds and the number of seeds on each?<n>Output: The weight of the apples without seeds is 2^9. It is the largest apple in the container.<n>The number of seeds on the other apples: 2^9=80.<n>So the apples with the most seeds are 80 times the weight of the apples with the fewest seeds. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where do farmers keep toothpicks? D: Which category is the correct answer?<n><n>Input:The average adult in Spain consumes 1.85 kilograms of meat a year. Which of the following categories is false? A. It is not a national holiday B. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How does this relate to the temperature of the water in your blood?  1 part per million divided by 4 parts per million = 0.040133.  So the total number of parts in your blood in the summer months is 4 * 0.040133 = 4,024.  What percent of this is water?  4 * 0.04010033 = 4,023.  Since water in the blood is 3,023 / 3 = 100, how much of this is water?<n>Output: 100<n><n>Input:A book about a girl named Jenny is on the best-seller list. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What happens to people playing games? Choices:  A: winning B: entertainment C: happiness D: cheating E: relaxation<n>Output:		 I like to win B, and I dislike cheating C, and I like to relax D, and I don't want to cheat<n>So the final answer that will be selected was A

How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:The master control for the Tardis is where in the main room? Choices:  A: nuclear power plant B: center C: basement D: main office E: bowel of the ship<n>Output:		 If the master control is A, then the most valuable object in the Tardis would be the one in B. If B is the most valuable object, then the one in A is, in fact, the most valuable object. What is the most valuable object?<n>Input:A the center B the basement D the main office E the colonizer<n>Output: If B the center D E the colonize is most valuable object A the ship is the most valuable object = 60*2=<<60*2=120>>120<n>So the final answer = 120<n><n>input:A is the center b the basement D the ship<n>output:A > B > D > E > C<n><n>Input:John has three large suits but only one small suit. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. One player from each side scores a goal and a goal from the third team. The third goal scorer gets 1 point for each goal. A team with three players on the scoreboard will score an average of 3 points per game.<n>Output:If three teams have three players on the scoreboard, then A scored two goals, B a goal and C a goal. That would give A three points and B four points. That would be three goals by B and C combined to give B four points. Then the team with the three point average would get three points. On the other hand, if four teams had three players on the scoreboard and each one scored two goals and each one got two goals from the other teams, then A would get two points and B three points. On the same page, if three or more teams scored on one player, then that team would get two points for the goal instead of three and three points for the goal instead. Three teams with three players on the board scored 1.5 points per game. If it had taken all three teams to score a goal, then a goal for each of them would not have counted as a goal. Teams with four or more players on the scoreboard have two players on the board. Each player scores one point. Teams have five players on the board. Team A earns two points and scores two points. Teams B and C with four and five players on the scoreboard each earn three points. And teams D and E with four and five players each get four points. Each time a game is played, the players of each team who scored an equal amount of goals get one point for each goal. If three teams scored an equally equal number of goals, then any combination of the three would give each team an average of 3 points for the game. Team A scored 10 points for all 10 goals. On the other hand a team with four players on the scoreboard would start with only 5 points, and two points for each additional player scored.<n><n>Input:A man is eating a steak, potatoes and peas. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where could you find a bookstore? Choices:  A: town B: carpeting C: city D: phone book E: magazines<n>Output:		 A is correct, B is incorrect. D is a different kind of store.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. Choices:  A: build family together B: fall in love C: make love D: complete E: distance themselves<n>Output:		 If a lover is not likely to fulfill all of the listed options C, D, and E, they probably should break up with her because of the risk of falling in love or having children together:<n>R = 2^(1 - A/100) * E<n>R=2^(2 - A/100) = (A + B/100)^(2 + C/100) + (E + D/100).<n>So R is a good approximation to C<n>R = 200/100 x E^A/100 = 200*10^25 = 2,000<n>So the final answer here is 2,000 or 2,000,000<n><n>Input:You only get six months with your lover in your life, in which case, you can only have sex a couple of times every six months. It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What often happens after a long day of traveling? Choices:  A: sickness B: motion sickness C: relocation D: jet lag E: fatigue<n>Output:		 Travel sickness is described as a feeling of discomfort and is commonly experienced during long-distance travel.  Jet lags describes feeling tired and jet lags can be caused by a combination of: 1) long flight times, 2) the absence of sunlight on long flights, 3) motion sickness.  These factors can cause discomfort and exhaustion.<n><n>Answer these questions in the correct order.<n>Each answer is in the form of a question.  If you don't know the answer to one of these questions try these things: a) Look up information on the Internet, b) Visit a Web site that specializes in answering these questions, c) Ask your friends/family for their answers, d) Look up information on an appropriate Web site, and e) Compare the results of the different Web sites.<n><n>Answers for questions 1, 4, and 8 can be seen on this Web site (See http://www.nber.org/papers/w414.html ) but the answers for questions 9 and 10 are not available on that Web site yet. They are in the form of some research questions that require answers that range from "no answer" to "too complex for this Web site." One of the questions requires that you write down 3 (or less!) steps that are part of your answer. If the first three or less of those steps are not answered, write "not applicable." If the first three or fewer of those steps are answered, type either "solution" or "solution for." Then write the number on the correct answer as follows: 2:00pm (noon) -- 3:00pm -- 5:00pm -- 1:00pm (noon). I encourage you to read the article on "The History of World Cup Odds" on this Web site and to get an idea of what is involved in answering these questions. The best answer to all of these puzzles is probably "a."<n><n>You may see answers below in the answers to this blog post, as many of the questions are similar. Also, some of the answers are found on pages on this Web site that provide "answers to the same problems" or other similar answers.<n><n>Please consider using "google" to help you in your search for answers to some of the questions. "google" search is for: 1) search terms for web pages that may help you in answering one of these questions (and perhaps the other ones) b) search term to look up an article on a topic c)
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What happens when humans are exposed to noises? Choices:  A: pet the dog B: hear sounds C: have sex D: reproduce E: drive cars<n>Output:		  A: all human beings are attracted to dog noises  B: all human beings have dogs in their bedrooms in the dark<n>C: A: humans can feel human sound waves  B: A and B are both wrong  D: E is wrong<n><n>Input:<n>Adam buys one kilo of oranges, one kilo of grapes and one kilo of pineapples. The total cost of his purchases is $60. The price of one kilo of pineapple is $6.  His total number of purchased items is 100.  The total number of people who saw his purchases is 500. The total number of strangers who interacted with Adam on the trip that he was on is 12.  Let his total number of trips be 10. Find his average number of trips per day from the above numbers to 10.  Then find the difference (in miles) between his average number of trips and his price of one kilo.<n>Suppose his average number of trips for each day was 10 and his total number of people were 10.  His price of one kilo is $7. Then his average number of trips to the store was 5 and his total number of purchases was 25.<n>So his average number of trips each day was 4 and his total number of daily purchases was 25<n><n>Input:<n>Alice and her neighbor are walking home from the bus stop.  Alice has a map with her and the bus stop. Alice's friend stops to ask a question.  Then Alice sees that it is dark, so she starts to walk towards home.  Her friend has been trying to convince Alice to stay with them instead of walking home to avoid getting home. What happens to her if she refuses to walk to the bus stop at 10PM?<n>Output: Alice ignores friend and continues to walk home<n>It takes Alice 5 minutes to walk there. She is walking 5 miles, which is 5 miles and 25 minutes. Because the distance and time are equal, her price is $7.50/mile, which is $75/mile.  If she decided to walk home after the 10PM bus showed up at her bus stop, her average price from the previous day would have been $9.50/mile and her price for this single day would have been $78/mile.<n>Output: Since Alice ignores and continues to walk home, her average number of trips to and from the bus stop is 10/10=50/50.  Her price was $7.50-$7.5
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where is a likely place to view an old copy machine? Choices:  A: industrial area B: museum C: barn D: school E: office<n>Output:		 B, C, and D<n>B is the correct answer<n><n>Input:What can you expect to get for a year of full-time work after taxes and vacation leave are taken out?<n>Output:  The answer depends on the size of your family.<n><n>Input:Which year was it that Jim bought his house?<n>Output: Jim bought his house for the same price he did the year before.<n>Thus the "year" part is redundant<n><n>Input:How much do you think you'll pay in taxes this year?<n>Output: The tax rate varies from 18% to 38% depending on one's income<n>Thus the tax rate is redundant<n><n>Input and Output:This is a computer game that makes predictions using an equation.  Calculate the following probability that the game predicts the actual outcome of a scenario.  When you think through the game you notice that the goal of the game is to get the same outcome as the predicted outcome.  Calculate the number of times the game is correct and use that number to find the probability of your outcome.  Use this number to divide the probability by the number of correct outcomes to get the probability of your specific outcome.  Since 100 * 100 is 32, divide 32 by 10 to derive 100/32 = 10.  This can be used as a probability of winning.<n>Output: 20 times the odds of winning = 110<n><n>Input:The following two are two different animals.  Which one will be the fastest?  Answer: Which one has larger, stronger jaws?  Which one can eat more food in one time?<n><n>Input:If you divide 100 by 100 and multiply by 101, what is the result?<n>Output: 100 times 16 times 2 = 160<n><n>Input:Which can survive the largest earthquakes?  You had to use a computer program, not a guess.  Answer:  The animal with more of the solid rock is the one that survives the earthquakes.<n><n>Input and Output:"I'm gonna find out who did the crime and make them do some time."  "Here's a gun."  Now, the solution that you use depends entirely on how you interpret these two quotes.<n><n>Input:When you start a program in which 1000 lines of code are written, 10% of the code is not executable when completed. Choices: A:  B:  C:  D:  E:  warehouse<n>Output: A, B, C, D:<n><n>Input: The most popular beer among the residents of a bar is Carlsberg.  Only 2.5% of the patrons order it. So what is the cost of burning 100 litres of petrol?<n>Input: 100 litres of petrol = $1.90/100*1000*1000=$1610.<n>Output: 160 x $1.90 = $160<n>If you burn 300 litres of petrol in a year, you spend an impressive $80 a year on petrol<n>So you spent $80 a year<n>So the total cost of your 100 litres of petrol is $160<n>Your total annual expenditure was therefore $160.<n>Total expenditure = $160 x 100<n><n>Output: The number of people in a city is A. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. What is the average time the runner at home gets the runner at second (or third!) on base?<n>Output:The runner at second bases 90%.<n>So if the average is 100 ft. and the runner gets 90 ft. on home, the average is 90/2=<<100/2=100>>100 ft.<n>So the score is 0, because the average is 100<n><n>Input:What is the difference in the weight of the two sides of a door and the center?<n>Output:The difference in the weight is +5oz<n>The final question is +5oz<n><n>Input:The number of players in two baseball games is 6-7.  Three at first base have home runs and three are RBI players.  These players are on every pitch.  What team will score one more run, and who will not?<n>Output:The number of runs scored by the team 6-7 is 2.<n>So the final equation is 2+2=4<n><n>Input:The total distance travelled through three walls in a room is 75 ft.  If the rooms are 3x2, how many 2-foot-thick walls must be added to get the total distance?<n>Output:The total distance travelled in 3-foot-thick rooms is 5*3=15<n>So the final equation = 5*3=15+5 = 35<n>So the final answer<n><n>Input:There is a barbell and 10 barbells in one bar room.  Each of the 10 barbells weighs 4.5kg.  How many rows of the bar are there? A subway car can always be empty.<n>B. People never take a train.<n>C. The trains are usually full.<n>D. All of the above.<n>E. It says that on March 1 next year, it will tax soda at 5 cents per can.<n>Output: For the first year after the tax, the soda industry sold 7 billion cans of soda and 1 trillion bottles of soda.<n>So the first year of the tax is:<n>$1.3 billion(0.5 x 5c=0.5)<n>$30 billion<n>$72 billion<n>$240 billion<n>So the first taxes for the first year are:<n>$0.48 * 12c = $2.50<n>$64 billion<n>$240 billion $6.9 billion = $10.6 billion<n>Which of the following is not a problem?<n>Solution:<n>In this case, (3) is true because the tax applies to the initial tax period (year 1).<n>Solution: (9) is the answer because it’s both the correct and the right answer:<n>(A) The government wanted a tax on soda;<n>(B) the tax was originally planned for year 5;<n>(C) There will be an unlimited number of cans sold after the first year’s tax;<n>(D) In year 6, the tax will be raised to a dollar per can.<n>So, (A) is the correct answer.<n><n>Input: There are two identical pieces of food, A and B, which do not have different amounts of fat, carbohydrates and protein in them and which are priced identically in a supermarket. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where might you have cake with your ice cream? Choices:  A: earth B: movie C: party D: served cold E: freezer<n>Output:		  where you have cake with your dessert, the ice cream will be cold.  your dessert will be served at room temperature.  dessert is served at room temperature.<n>So let's sum up the results for now, you can see that in order to get full ice cream, you need to remove the dessert from the freezer.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:The policemen wanted to clear the scene of the accident, so what did they do to traffic? So if the ball is kicked 40 yards out then the player who kicks it 40 yards out can return it 100 yards further. So it is possible to return a 100-yard ball to the start of the game if you are 50 yards further out than the ball was kicked.<n>Output: A ball is kick 50 yards. 60 yards out on a 30-yard box would have the ball travel 80 yards out. If the ball then bounces off an opponent it is possible that a player can return the ball a further distance (180 yards) than if it bounces off one of the goal posts. So if the ball was kicked 50 yards beyond the 30-yard box and then bounced off an opponent and is returned by the player, then it may reach a distance of 280 yards beyond the 30-year box.<n>So the final result is 280 + 60<n><n>Input:In football the number of goals scored are equal to the number of goals conceded for each team. Each of these results in two points for him. How many points can C get away with?<n>Output:C cannot get away with any attempt for points equal to or greater than 2.  If C attempts more than 2 attempts for points greater than 2, he gains no new points.  If he attempts more than 2 attempts, but not more than 2 consecutive, his average per attempt will increase by 1 point per attempt.  Any attempts that do not exceed 2 will have his average per attempt reduced by 1.<n>Output:C cannot shoot 30 total twomarks for 30 total points or less per attempt.  Any attempt that includes any attempt to shoot 30 total twomark for 30 total points at once, but that does not count as more than 2 attempts, will count as more than 2.<n>Output:C is limited to attempts equal to or greater than 40 total twomark attempts, or attempts equal to or less than 2 attempts.  Any attempt that is made with more than 40 twomark attempts for 40 total points at once or less than 2 attempts for a total of 80 for all attempts, is not counted towards C's total twomark attempts for any attempt less than 20 points.  Attempts scored before 2 attempts have been made is not counted towards C.<n><n>Output: A player has played for his team for 26 seasons. He plays for them every game when he is on the bench. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:How can an artist commemorate a horse forever. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What is a living thing with a lip? It is now 15 cents a gallon higher than in 2005.  The cost to fill up a tank has gone up by 55%.  The cost to fill a 15-gallon tank is $11.65.  In 2003 it only cost you $7.15 to fill it up.  The 2004 price was $11.65 but only $7.15 in the past 8 years.<n>Output: We need to make do without the current price of oil.  We would need to save money from the increases in gas prices and the cost of filling our cars.  Let us figure this out.  So what is our saving plan?  We will need to save enough to last a week (we will need 2.5 gallons per day for that week) so we can fill our cars with gas every day.  We can save money by using the gas station that is closest to our house and also has the most gas (like the grocery store).  Or we can just fill up every day with whatever gas is available.  Since we can save $55/15 gallons it is much cheaper to fill up every day than it is to save so much money on gasoline that we fill up our car every day. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Why would professionals playing sports not be able to compete? Choices:  A: pain B: mudslide C: sweating D: injuries E: rain<n>Output:		  A = pain B = mudslide C = sweaty D = injuries E = rain<n><n>Input: You are in your house and hear a car speeding past.  You ask yourself, "Is this person speeding because he cares only about his personal safety?  Or is he speeding to impress other people? "<n>Output: Which is the correct answer?<n><n>Input:You are at a party thrown by a woman named Rachel. Her friends are sitting at a table and are having a snack to start their meal.  You see another man at the table with them and immediately, you are attracted to him.  At first, you feel attracted to him and the desire to talk to him is strong.  However, some thoughts are running through your head.  You ask yourself "will my friends find him attractive?"  How would they respond to the fact that you have just started talking to another man?  Would they think it was strange to have a friend spending time with another man?  Would you be hurt if they became upset?  What do you need to know before you proceed with your conversation with the man?  Answer "A"<n>Output:  A. There are some friends that may respond positively to<n>the fact that he has just started talking about with another<n>man.  They may even join your conversation and be<n>glad you decided to meet another man.  They would be<n>reached quickly.  They may not be upset at all.  You would<n>be hurt if she became upset.<n>The first man at the table, would be happy and<n>excited that you have decided to go with a<n>friend and take part in the party.  Some other<n>friends would feel confused and jealous.  They would<n>think this was unusual for him to spend time with<n>a woman.  He would not be at all upset If she become<n>upset or would not know what to do.  He would be<n>very happy to be able to attend the party and enjoy<n>it with you.  Some men would think it was weird for<n>her to participate in a party with another man.  They<n>would not know what to do and would be hurt.<n>B. The first man at the table will not be happy and<n>exciting that you have decided to ask another woman to<n>talk with.  He would not say<n>anything.  He would ask, "What are you doing<n>talking to him."  Other friends would probably not be<n>att
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:When a newborn's eyes open for the first time it will be the first time the ever? Choices:  A: tear up B: see light C: fill with tears D: be happy E: glass over<n>Output:		 The first time its eyes ever open, those tears will be tears of happiness<n><n>Input:The following three numbers are divisible by 10:  1, 21, 2  When the number 12 is added to 3 it becomes 1 + 36  When the number 7 is added to 3 it become 1 + 17  The following three numbers are evenly divisible by 3:  1, 3, 4  Add 13 to 3 and the answer becomes 2 + 4  When the number 14 is added to 3 it comes up as 2 + 3  When 14 is added to 3, 2 + 9 is the answer  When 14 is added, the 9 is a prime number  When 14 is added the 9 is not a prime number
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How many yellow cards are given?<n>Output: The total number of yellow cards given out in the game is 2+1<n>So the total number of yellow cards that would have been given was 2+1*2*300=300+1*300=900<n>That means 900/2=<<900/2=16>>16 yellow cards<n>So the final answer this week is 16<n><n>Input: Two cups of coffee are put in a pot.  The pot is heated on the stove for twenty minutes.  Then it is added to a cup of milk and boiled for six and eight minutes respectively. Let them sit for 24 hours.  Then they are drunk. The coffee costs $3.  The milk price is $2.45.  The final product is $3.40<n>Output: The total coffee price is $3.40 + $2.45+ $2.95=$3.65.<n>That is $3.65<n><n>Input: Four men take the red light.  If their cars were both on the road, one car must drive ahead of the other one.  The other car must make a U turn to get behind the other.  The other car's speed is 70 miles an hour.  The other's speed is 50 miles an hour.  They each get a chance to run a ten thousand foot marathon for free. The first one to finish needs to return to where they started and start again from the beginning.<n>The first one to finish has to do the ten thousand foot marathon again.<n>It costs $400. The first one that manages to complete the marathon costs $400 x 10,000= $1,000,000. The second costs $150 x 20,000= $400,000, the third $90 x 30,000= $250,000, the fourth $75 x 40,000= $250<n>And the fifth one earns $10,000 for doing the tenth mile of the marathon. The total is $100,000.  Now that is $100,000 in cash<n>The final answer is a 100,000 x 10,000/100,000=200,000,000<n><n>Input: Four cars take the red light. Now it will be 240 outlets. Now it will take 3/12*240*120=$480*3=900 to charge the RV. That is 10 miles away from the rest area.<n>Input: James is a long distance runner. How much distance is it to the local hospital?<n>Output: The nearest hospital is 15 miles away. That works out to be 50 miles away. It costs James $15 to drive to the hospital. How far will Adam be able to walk before he needs to use 10 gallons of gas?<n>Input: Adam's new bicycle requires 2 gallons of fuel to fully charge each time he charges the batteries. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What makes people happy when it is surprising and unexpected? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. How many humans does it take to maintain one plane?<n>Output:<n>One person to operate it = $40<n>Four people to operate = $350<n>Three people to operate = $120<n>Two people to operate = $60<n>Three people to operate= $20<n>So one crew member = $20 = $20 = $110<n>Four crew members = $120 = $40 = $90<n>So 4 crew members = $140 = $160 = $200<n>So the full cost of the plane is $220/person or $120/seat or $60/hour.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:When someone falls from a mountain it will lead them to? Choices:  A: too much B: act dead C: die D: rush E: explode<n>Output:		Falling off a mountain reduces your speed and allows you to stop your fall.  Also it sends you backwards faster.<n>Also it turns you and every object around you into a single mass which will lead you to? Choices: A: too B: act dead C? D: die E: rush F: die<n>Output:So falling from a mountain does not cause you to die.<n>Also it sends you backwards faster<n>Also it allows you to stop your falling momentum.<n>Also the amount of fall you sustained during the fall no? Choices: A:-too B:-act dead C:-dead D:-rush E:-die<n>Output:So falling off a mountain does not cause death and the fall is not traumatic.<n>Also your fall is not traumatic so you will feel no pain.<n>Also your falling momentum decreases due to gravity so you will not fall further.<n>So your fall will slow you down and your speed will drop to an equilibrium.<n>So you will feel no pain<n>So your falling momentum increases due to gravity and you will gain speed.<n>So the amount of fall you sustain decreases.<n>So you will continue falling until the fall slows again.<n>So the amount you sustain decreases and you fall downward again.<n>So you continue falling until your fall slows again.<n><n>Input: John lives in the U.S. and pays $100 per month for electricity. In the past 6 months and with usage of the new solar energy system, his bill went down by $30 per month.   How much less did it come to?<n>Output:With no new electricity being generated, John's bill rose by 30* $100=$<<30*$100=480>>580$.  That's 20% less<n>So it cost $480-$480=<<480-20=560>>560 to produce electricity.  That is 20% less<n>That means it cost 2.9*$480-$480=<<360>>360 dollars per month to produce electricity.<n>So it cost $120-$120=$480-$480=<<240>>240 dollars per month to produce power.<n>That is 3.1*$120-$120=$480/$480=<<360>>180 dollars per month to produce energy<n>That means it cost 480 dollars to produce the energy that you need to keep yourself alive.<n>So it cost you 960 dollars to produce the energy you need to keep yourself safe at night.<n>So it would cost you 960 dollars to survive.<n><n> inputs<n>
