One month ago, James went to Hong Kong and did not drink any wine either. Both times James' alcohol content was at the level recommended by physicians (0.2 ounces of wine per lb. of body weight). The body weight is calculated by the body mass index: BMI - kg/m2<n>Output: It does not take 5 weeks for individuals to reach the recommended daily alcohol limit.<n>Weighing in at 833 lbs/394 kg, James has a BMI of 30, which is the definition of adult overweight<n>The recommended daily alcohol limit for James is a maximum 2 ounces/60 ml (1% ABV) every 24 hours.<n><n>Input:If the price of the car was $1,000 but was discounted 20% in 20 years, how long would it be before you bought a new car?<n>Output: The price of a car will never be 20% cheaper than its original price, so it depends on how long ago the discount occurred. The answer for $1,000 is $1,000 + 20%. That number is the starting point for the question, and will eventually increase as the discount is added to.<n>Output:<n>1.) The original price of the car will always be more than twice the price in 20 years to the same person because the car will either be worth more or less<n>2.)
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Choices:  A: problems B: not noticeable C: deflation D: economic instability E: eat cake<n>Output:		 The current inflation will cause problems if it is ignored. There are many ways in which inflation would cause problems, some short-term and some long-term.<n>For example: The government would have to implement tax cuts, and the spending cuts that might accompany those cuts would affect wages, which would cause problems for employees, businesses, and consumers in the short-term.  It is also possible that a trade-off between government spending and increasing interest rates could be proposed, which would bring inflation under control. There are others. One example would be the decline of currency. Choices:  A: carpeting B: magazines C: strip mall D: city E: applesauce<n>Output:		 A, B and C.<n><n>Input: An average American makes an average of $30,000 over his lifetime. How much has a $30K person increased his lifetime earnings?<n>Output: The person gains $30k of lifetime earnings by retiring at 65, saving $5k every year after that, saving $40k every year after that. This person earns a total of $90k for his lifetime.<n>Output: If we take the $90k person who will retire at 65, work 1 hour a day for 40 days, invest 100% of his savings at his age and earn an average of $30/day, and then work another hour a day the next 40 days to save another $20/day and then work another hour every day until he is 65, we can save him $2k/year and earn an overall lifetime income of $100k, instead.<n>Output:<n>If we assume that the person has no financial worries, he can live comfortably for the rest of his life on this $100k income.<n>But if he has to live in a place where the economy has gone south, for example with no job prospects and no money to spend, he will certainly need to supplement his income by working another job for a month a year, and maybe another month every year to earn more than the average for his age.<n>Output:<n>Even with a modestly successful financial strategy, the total amount of return on investment is still less than his lifetime returns. So he can live for a few years on only the maximum he saved and have a much smaller lifetime total return.<n>Output:<n>On the other hand, if he invested in a great business and made an investment strategy that worked well, he could make an annual average of $300k over a lifetime even with a modestly successful strategy. But that is still less money than his net worth will allow for.<n>Output:<n>Thus, if one is going to work more than 40 days per year to live for a while, the absolute amount of return on investment must be smaller than $100k, to live comfortably. But if one works 40 days per year to raise enough money (and still invest his profits) to take advantage of market conditions while one is still young enough to live comfortably, he may be able to make quite a bit more than the typical American, and potentially earn a lot more to a very good degree because of it.<n>Output:<n>This is a little bit different from a scenario where all
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. The next time he went to class he wasn’t asked why he had a shirt on.  Jack had a shirt. Every morning he put on his shirt and walked out into the sunlight without being bothered by classmates or teachers. Just when he was about to stand in front of the classroom door, he realized that there was a big black stain on his shirt. He looked down and his shirt was tinged with red. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. For each trip, the accounts are credited by three different transaction numbers. The number of trips and their corresponding numbers appear below:   True  False  True  False<n><n>Input:James had an extra tank for his tank on his car. He made four trips to the store. Total of 4 trips - 4 numbers in the accounts   True  False<n>Total of 4 trips - 4 transactions - 4 numbers  True<n>Total of 4 trips-4 transactions-4 numbers  False<n>Total of 3 trips-3 transactions-3 numbers  True<n>Total 3 trips-3 transactions - 3 numbers  False<n>Total 2 trips-2 transactions-2 numbers  True<n>Total 2 trips-1 transaction-1 number  False<n>Total 1 trip-1 number-1 number  False
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:The man didn't like getting out of bed and stepping on the cold tile, so where did he put carpeting? The greatest being that the intelligence ever gave us as an intelligence is the two tens, for the number of degrees of the latitude of our globe is 2 tens (2 x 3+3 + 3 x 3+3 for 300).<n>Output: If the number of the stars at the time of writing this sentence is one and a half million, two tens of the latitude must be at least one million, and of course at least three millions must be at least one tens. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Choices:  A: cattle ranch B: countryside C: grocery store D: slaughterhouse E: dairy farm<n>Output:		 By not allowing the heifer to live in the cow barn A, John's farm does not pay the grazing fees so that the heifer does not spend extra time in the barn. While the heifer may spend extra time in the cow barn, each day she spends in the barn pays for the additional grazing fees.  By allowing the heifer to reside in the cow barn, the heifer spends none of her time in the pasture she was grazing in (unless she goes in to relieve herself) and spends one more day in the barn. By allowing the heifer one extra day and grazing for an extra 3 cents a day, John did not spend the extra 3 cents a day on an additional day on the other two farm animals.  For each night that she spends in the barn, John does not incur a payment on grazing fees for the cows. Thus, John saves $2.50 which would have been spent on an additional day on each of the other two farm animals in the pasture.  For example, if John has 60 cows, John's payment on grazing fees was $20 and each of the 60 cows spent 3 cents a day on extra day in the pasture.<n><n>Input: How many miles of wire did it take to build 2 miles of fence from the beginning to the end of the field.<n>Output: You are asked to choose the value of the miles of wire built, the time it took to build it, and the total cost of the fence.<n>Input: The cattle grazed in the field for one year. Average day length for the field was 15 miles. The cattle traveled 6.5 miles in a day. The field had a wire cost of $1,000 and the fence cost of $300<n>Output: You were asked to choose the distance of the completed miles, the cost of the wire, and the amount of money you cost to build<n><n>Input:A field was filled with 1 ton of fertilized fertilizer spread on a surface of 1 acre. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:People celebrate by going places and riding rides.  What's one obvious place people might go to celebrate? Choices:  A: state park B: opera C: disneyland D: carnival E: park<n>Output:		       A: state park.   B: opera.  D: carnival.  E: park<n>So a state park is obvious from the first two answers.  However, it is harder to identify. Which of the following is greater?<n>Output:  the total number of people who watched the World Cup in the stadium was 30,000.  They paid $180,000,000/annum to watch the World Cup.<n><n>input: In a normal family's income, each member earns $10,000/month. They may also like it more because it makes them feel better. They have 5 friends.  Which of the listed ingredients will give them the best taste?<n>Output:   If they eat together as a group one is   (a): chicken  (b): bread  (c): cheese  (d): chicken<n>(e): broccoli  (f): ham  (g): pizza   (h): pizza<n>So 5 of them like a particular food. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Lilly owns the only kosher deli in the area.  She isn't in a heavily populated area.  Where might she live? Choices:  A: food court B: jerusalem C: new york city D: jewish community E: town<n>Output:		 The cost of her deli is equal to all other deli's in the area.  It's the highest cost option.<n>It can be found at:  http://www.lillydeli.com<n><n>Input:Jill purchased a new camera this week.  The new camera is a Sony P30.  It takes 1/2 an hour to charge fully.  The battery lasts a couple of years.  What is the price of the camera?<n>Output: $1000<n>If Jill buys a new camera every 6 months on average, the price of the camera would increase by $100 every 6 months.<n>Therefore Jill spends $1000 every 6 months which would = 60 x $100 = $120<n>Thus Jill spends 120+60=160=200$ which is equal to 60/160=$60.<n>So the final price is $60<n><n>Input:<n>a. what is the price of a computer?<n>b. which is the cheapest price of computer you can find?<n>c. how many computer would you get if you buy one computer and all other hardware would be free?<n>Answer:<n>c. A. computer cost $300.<n>Answer:c only counts as $300<n><n>Input:<n>A. A<n>b. Choices:  A: smile B: shake hands C: express gratitude D: say you're welcome E: appreciate compliment<n>Output:		 If I wanted to thank someone (A) and shake hands (B), I have to smile and let him think the job was done.  With A, I could express gratitude if I wanted and I could say I appreciate his compliment if I did.  With B, I have to say "thank you" but then I don't take another step.  The E option wouldn't be that helpful because I can imagine how to thank even an absent one and saying it out of context would not have the impact I am imagining.<n><n>Input:If you gave a very generous gift to someone but they never received it what would you do? Choices: A: tell them thank you B: say I'm sorry C: say it's not much but I appreciate it D: say you're sorry E: leave it out of conversation<n>Output: If you gave a very generous but never received gift (A), you should tell someone "thank you" just to show your appreciation.  This will mean you may have to talk them into receiving it at that time and if they still don't take it, simply say you're sorry.  If they still don't accept it, just let it go and say "that's okay".  If they do accept it, you'd be better off going for the A route and thanking them then leaving it out of conversation if you don't want it to seem too big a gift and awkward.  Remember, the gift needs to be generous enough to receive a thank you and a thank you needs to be generous enough as well.  The most important part of a thank you is to say that you appreciated it and not to ask for an exchange (I appreciate you) or ask for something for nothing that you can give them in return (no, thank you).<n><n>Input:If a stranger walked by you one day and then gave you a piece of music by Mozart, Mozart's family and the composer himself would approve. But you still have to buy the piece of music and not just listen to it. If you were to listen to the Mozart, what is Mozart's reaction to you?   Output: If Mozart heard you listening to his music he may be pleased with this act from you.  He should be pleased because you appreciate his music and the appreciation should bring you closer (and perhaps a little closer too).  It should be a good feeling for him.  So the initial reaction will be "congratulations".  Even though Mozart has approval
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What happens to people when they do not have enough food? He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:There are many cubicles in the office, they all have computers for employees to what? Choices:  A: teach B: cost money C: do work D: be productive E: help people<n>Output:		 The cubicles all have computers for employees<n>So for each one there are:<n>1 computer cost<n>30 computer time<n>300 computer productivity<n>That amount is:<n>1 computer cost+30 computer time<n>300 time computer productivity<n>So for each cubicle there are:<n>1 cubicle productivity+300 computer productivity<n>That totals to:<n>1 cubicle 1 productivity+300 computer productivity=<n>150 cubicles productivity+300 computer productivity =<n>180<n><n>Input:The question above contains a formula for the sum of two numbers but for all five words, we have to find the formula for each single answer without looking at the solution (for example:<n><n>Supposed you have five $10 bills of the same denomination, one has $10 and one has $5. Then divide the total value of the bills, $50, by 5. If you also have a $100 bill, sum up the total value of the $100 bill and divide that answer by five.<n><n>Input: The value of the number two in a number of $10 bills is 1.  So what is the value of one in the five $10 bills?<n>Output: So for each of the $10 $5 bills there are 5 $1 bills and 5 $2 bills.  For each of the $10 bills there are 10 $10 bills and 10 $200 bills (if it were a $100 bill).  So for each $10 bill there are 100 $5 bills and 100 $100 bills<n>That means 100*10=280<n>So for example, if one of the $100 bills had 1000 pieces of money, so the number of $5 and $10 bills is 5500$ 10 500.  In that case, divide each $10 bill by the sum of the thousand pieces of money.<n>So for example if the 1000 pieces of money in a $100 bill was $100, then the answer is 1250. So the answer is 3650.<n><n>Input: Suppose you make a sale and you need to pay your accountants $200.  You have $40 in the register and $60 in the cash register. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Choices:  A: bright B: pointed C: correct D: acute angled E: clear<n>Output:		 Bright is the answer because obtuse is incorrect. Bright can be either a noun or a verb, depending on context. Bright is the answer because it matches the context. Choices: Acute Angle is the answer because it isn't clear. Acute Angle can be either a noun (acute angles) or a verb (points). Choices: Bright and Pointed are the answer because obtuses are incorrect. Choices: Acuity is the answer because it is clear. Acuity can be either a noun: acute angles;  or a verb: points, points, or acute angles. Choices: Clear can be either a noun : acute angles that are acute. Choices: Clear and Pointed can be the answer because obtuseness is unclear. Choices: Clear, Pointed, A: A; B: a point; C: C; D: D; E: E.<n>And they were right<n><n>Output: A. Bright B. A point C. C; D. D; E. E; E.<n>And they said they were<n>Correct<n><n>Input: If a person were to eat an infinite supply of grapes, the same grape would grow in each of their mouths.  It is true that grape juice can grow in your mouth, but it is not possible to have your own grape juice. What is the correct statement?<n>Output: A. True B. False C. False D. False; C. True; D. False; E. False; E. True<n>Because they had to be right<n><n>Input: The following people had four children: Bob, Doug, Joe and Charlie. The first four were identical. How many copies of each child are there?<n>Output: A: 1. Joe 2. Charlie 3. Bob<n>B. 1. Charlie 2. Joe 3. B<n>Correct<n><n>Input::The only possible answer to this question is A. You should be able to say: What is the difference between these four people?<n>Output: A is the only possible answer. You can't say: What is the most important difference between what we're talking about here?<n>Correct<n><n>Input & Output: If one can drive a car, how much longer, in hours, could the following person drive the car? (No car = no answer)<n>Output: A hour B hour C hour D hour E hour F hour G hour H hour I hour J hour K hour L hour M hour N hour O hour
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:The artist knew that this was the peak of his fandom, so he decided it was time for cashing in by doing what? Choices:  A: selling out B: happy C: fishing D: receiving money E: getting paid<n>Output:		 Selling Out A is Cash in  The artist took A and paid it out B was Fish out  The fisherman received the money E was Fished  So the answer is Cash in<n><n>Input: When a man and a woman love each other very much, they move in together. They decorate the house with furniture and plants from the store that sells flowers and gardening supplies. However, when there is not enough money left for the mortgage payment, the man takes out a loan against his future earnings and they get a second mortgage.  How much would that second mortgage be worth in today's dollars? Output: The interest paid on a first mortgage is $1200 and that of a second mortgage will be $1600.  How much does that difference cost in today's dollars?<n>Input: The man and the woman do not live together. They live in separate houses. The man makes the payments on the first mortgage and pays $600, and makes the second mortgage payment of $600.  How much would the interest on the second mortgage be worth in dollars today? Output: If both the salaries are equal, the man is earning $30,000 a year and the woman is earning $18,000. After his wife's death and his first mortgage payment, the man makes $23,700, and when the second mortgage is paid, he makes $20,900.  The woman makes only a third of what the man is making at the end of the year.  How much does she earn in today's dollars?output: If there is one third more money to spend after her mortgage is paid, is the woman's earnings equal to the man's?  If they both earned the same amount, what was the woman's salary in today's dollars?  If their salaries were equal, the woman should expect all the money she is earning in today's dollars.  How should she take this?output: If they have enough money after paying the mortgage and if she is paid the same amount as the man, she should be able to send him the money that is equivalent to 30% of the man's monthly salary.  That is the standard rate.  If she needs 35% more money, she could increase how much she is making.  But if the man is making 35%, and she makes 30%, her earnings will not change all that much.  How much more is she asking for?output: If the man is making $35,000 and the woman is making 30, she will ask $50,
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. Choices:  A: church B: theatre C: large city D: water fountain E: central park<n>Output:		There are 1000*1000 statues<n><n>Input:There is a bridge between the coast and the middle of the continent.  It is two stories tall, and the longest single span on the continent.  The people crossing the bridge go by boat.  What percent of the people that cross it by boat in a day, does that also count as one person crossing the bridge?<n>Output: The number of people crossing the bridge is 10^10*100*9 = 100,000 people<n>So the number of people crossing the beach by boat in a day is 100,000*(100-9)*100 = 9,000<n>For this number to be half of the entire human population on the continent, it would need to be half of the people in the world<n>So the final answer percentage is =2^300*(900-9)*2^300 = 11,000<n>And the population is 0.11*10^9 = 0.0011 people<n><n>Input:If you wanted to have 100 million people, you could put two people in each of ten rooms in a house, and they would sleep in every room for 2 weeks.  You then take six months to collect all the food and water that you can and ship it off to another country in the same fashion.  What percent would it take you to ship all the good food and drink to the next country?<n>Output: If you want to have 100 million people in ten room, you need to fill them with 100 people each.  You need to get food and water to each room for 2 weeks then ship it off.  Since everyone else has 100 people in each of their 10 rooms, it takes 2 weeks to fill the rooms with food and drink.<n>So the final percentage is 4*10^9 = 8<n><n>Input:To what do two pounds of potatoes equal? Your answer: To one pound of potatoes, one pound of sugar equals one pound of wheat<n>Your answer is not wrong, but it is slightly wrong.  First of all, sugar is not "one pound of wheat."  The amount of the amount of sugar that you put on a potato is not one "pound" of wheat and not one "pound" or "pound" of sugar.  The amount of sugar that is put on a potato is the amount of sugar that is added.  Therefore, this answer is actually incorrect.  The correct answer is 2 pounds of sugar = 1 pound of wheat, but with the right spelling.

How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:A person is alone in the woods and wounded, what should he do? Choices:  A: amount to nothing B: visit relatives C: charming D: doctor himself E: cross street<n>Output:		 A. He should give up C. He should cross D. He should see people<n>So he should cross the street.<n><n>Input:The goalkeeping coach at Madrid is very strict. The players will have to improve by at least 100 per day, and if they do, the coach will have to stay.  How many players do you think will improve by 100 per day?  Output:A. At least 100 B. Around 150 C. Around 150 D. Around 250<n>So I think both A and D have happened<n>Maybe D has happened just not A<n><n>Assignments & Resources Questions<n><n>1. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:The human looked down longingly as he sat in the orbiting space station, what did he miss? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week. Then add 2 to low and count it as 1. Also if you need to know the lowest cost, add 2 to high and count it as 2. Choices:  A: relaxation B: good things in life C: admiration D: own house E: needs money<n>Output:		 The average annual salary for an executive in America is $280,000 dollars. Assuming each executive can only spend $1,000 per year per vacation, then $280,000 + $280,000 = $1,800 and $880,000 = $2,100. So vacation expenses would be $1,800 per month, or $900 per year, without a savings account. The figure does not change if the executive does not spend $1,000 each year.<n>Input: If Adam spends 9 months in Italy, it takes 10% of his annual salary to do all the things he wanted to do in Italy. So the answer is not correct.<n><n>Input: John drives a car. That car costs only $10,000 to repair.  The cost for fuel is also only $10,000. What is the total for the car?<n>Output: The total savings in the first year of using a car is the sum of all the money saved on gas and repairs.<n>In the year after owning the car, John drives a car a total of 50% of the time, when no one else is using the vehicle.  That is, a total of $3,080 is saved in 1 year's time.  So $2,000.50 is saved. The total savings for the year are $3,080.50 = $10.50 per month, or $40 per year.  The sum of all the savings for the year is $10.

A: 15, B: 100,C: 10,D: 45<n>Input: You can buy the same number of stars at the time the new star is born. How many stars will you see in the next few months? A: 150,B: 500,C: 1,D: 60<n>Output: You will have 500 stars by the time the new star reaches age 13.<n>Output: 2 stars. That means that you see 150 stars after the new star goes supernova.<n>Output: 3 Stars. This means that you see 1 hundred stars on Earth at the same time as the star before it went supernova.<n>Output; 2:0:9:15:55:30,1:0:1:8:35<n><n>Input:A gas station must have a price list every day. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:The clothing was extremely expensive compared to other places, where was it likely purchased? Choices:  A: cinema hall B: mall C: department store D: closet E: shop<n>Output:		 The shirt cost $35 and the pants $27.<n>So they were $35-$27=40$40<n>So that's an extra $10-$12<n>Total would be: $40-$27=60$60<n>So the final answer would be 60<n><n>Input:The three girls on the bus had to find the perfect pair of underwear. There was a shop within walking distance and it was the one with the most choices.  Choice 1: The shop with the fewest choices B: the shop with the most choices C: the shop which was easiest to find. D: the shop which might have a surprise in the bra. E: the shop which wasn't a secret. F: the one which took all of the time. G: the other shop which was too far away<n>Output: They selected the bra with the least choices<n>So they selected the bra which was easiest to find<n>Total would be: ~60$~60<n>So the final answers would be 60 and 60<n><n>Input:  You can buy 2 kg of onions at the store for $3 each.  1kg of onions costs $18. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where would a restaurant put a candle? Choices:  A: dimly lit room B: kitchen C: wall D: table E: birthday cake<n>Output:		 There is a candle in the kitchen.<n><n>Input: A player is in the lead for the most goals scored by a player in a game in a season. How many goals does he have in the lead?<n>Output: If the player has a lead of 300/3, his goal tally would be 290/2 = 290<n><n>Input:John has a budget of 15 dollars for rent.  If the food cost of his entire meal is equal to 15 dollars, how much will his rent be? People talk child like to him when they have no problem telling him that he needs to work harder or that he can do better.  C. When people talk child like to, he usually feels like he's not good enough to do well enough for them.  D. People don't talk child like to, but rather use him as a child like prop.  E. People talk child like when they believe that he is just too smart to be in any way special.  F. People don’t talk child like to when they think he is just too dumb to have any intelligence.  G. People who do talk child like actually do something else that gives them a sense of importance about what they think they are doing and the results they are getting.  H. People who talk child like think that he just wants attention and affirmation.<n>So if you say he's smart or a child then his answer is probably A. His answer is different if you say he has special potential. If you say he has special opportunity, then all of a sudden he is A and not just smart, or special potential.  For people who say he is a disability, his answer is different.<n><n>input: There is an island about 250 kilometers off the coast of China, and in it are a group of villagers who are farming an agricultural property. During the harvest of 2013, the villagers built a new factory in the new island which produces a food product with a price tag of $60.00  The factory is equipped with an automated system to process produce. The cost of the food product is $60.00 and the produce can be sold in all of the nearby towns with a price tag of less than 1 US dollar per serve. The total cost of the food product for the year is $600.00 and the market price of the product is $4.50.<n>In the past 3 years, the local market for vegetables was $50.00 and there were no customers willing to pay $60.00 for a single serve in the market. In comparison, in the new factory, there could be multiple meals a day for more than 100 people each day if the factory was producing an average of 200 servings a day.  The total cost of the farm farm, the equipment rented to run the production system, and the marketing cost of the product to the
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:A person with children might have a lot of plastic things in what place? Choices:  A: cupboard B: cabinet C: own home D: everything E: garbage dump<n>Output:		 cupboard A C E garbage dump  So we have this table<n>1 cabinet 1 cupboard 0 cabinet 0 cabinet 1 cupboard 1 cupboard 1 cabinet 1 cupboard 1 cabinet 3 cupboards 1 cupboard 2 cupboard 2 cupboard 1 cupboard 2 cupboards 2 cupboards 1 cupboard 3 cupboards 1 cuphouse<n><n>Input: James is playing marbles.  The number of marbles that he receives depends how many players he has.<n>Output: James receives five marbles<n>That means that the number of marbles that James receives depends on the number of players he has with him<n><n>Input: a number of people came to the party on sunday. A can of soda costs $8 A can of soda can cost $10 A can of soda contains 10 grams of sugar A can of soda contains 11 grams of sugar A can is worth 16 cents. Choices:  A: efficiency B: getting work done C: marriage D: finishing up E: results<n>Output:		If the likely ceremony is A, the amount of time and money spent proposing is 860 minutes which is 860 divided by 30 equals 860 = 560. If the unlikely ceremony is B, the amount of time spent proposing is 540 minutes which is 540 divided by 30 equals 540 = 220. If the unlikely ceremony was C, the amount of time dedicated to the proposal is 40 minutes which is 40 divided by 30 equals 60 minutes. If the unlikely ceremony that was D, the amount of time required to the proposal is 40 seconds which is 40 divided by 60 equals 60=60 minutes. If the unlikely marriage that was E that was to propose was to get a ring, then the bride would have to spend a minute and a half to the proposal and there would be a minimum of 120 seconds before the ring is put on to the finger.<n>Output:If the likelihood of A is 80%, the likelihood of B is 20%, and the likelihood of C is 80%, then for each of the 860 minutes spent on proposing there was 40 seconds spent on the proposal. Therefore, each time a bride was required to get a ring she had to spend 4 seconds.<n>Output:If there are 860 minutes of effort for each proposal, an hour would be required.<n>output:If 860 minutes is spent, a half hour per proposal would be spent on each proposal. Therefore, a minimum of 360 minutes would take to complete getting rings for the weddings.<n>Output:If an hour has been spent, then 2 hours in total has been spent. If 2 hours has been spent, a minimum of 3 hours would be required. The total amount required to get a ring for each wedding is 120 hours, therefore this wedding has taken 36 hours to get the rings. Therefore this wedding has taken 2 hours and 12 minutes to get the rings.

How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Eating breakfast with a large family leads to a pile of what in the sink? Choices:  A: fullness B: underwear C: bad breath D: better day E: dirty dishes<n>Output:		 If half the family doesn't eat breakfast, it results in 6 rolls of toilet paper being used<n><n>Input:<n>Your car has the same number of miles on it as the one you bought new.<n>In what ways will you need to drive your car less?<n>Output:<n>You are given a new Hyundai. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:If I wanted to store my chess pawn when I wasn't using it, what would be a good place for that? The C situation is an exception to that since it is more like a couch or a console PC.  In the D situation it might be fine to place it on a table, but you might think its weird to have it on an office table.  In the E and F situations the situation may be less wierd because they are all like TV sets or consoles.  What do you think? Can you think of a location besides a desk or a couch?<n><n>Input:When a person receives a positive credit rating, a letter from a creditor is sent to the person saying that he or she may close an account they hold at that credit card or company for any reason other than dishonesty or bankruptcy. What do you think about this?<n>Output:How would you define dishonesty or bankruptcy? Answer: If the debt was not paid, and the creditor did not honor their word, then a dishonesty or bankruptcy would occur. Answer: In other words, yes, a person would have to close the account.  Question: Was the amount of money the creditor demanded too large to handle, or did they just not honor their word? Answer: Probably not too large.  Question: Did the creditor honor their word?  Answer: Probably not.  Question: Did he or she honor the promise he made to the creditor?  Answer: Probably, although with a poor record, I can't see them doing that.  Question: In retrospect, was the creditor honest in the transaction? Answer: Probably not.<n>Question: The company might have a poor record as well. If there are two people on the account with different credit ratings, can an honest person place an order with one and a dishonest person with the other? Answer: Definitely.  Question: Let’s say the first is dishonest, and the second honest. If it’s possible to purchase either account from any other seller at a substantial discount, then what’s different about the situation from the honest account buyer from the dishonest account seller? Answer: They are both in danger of losing money.  Question: Is the problem the honesty or the dishonesty of the seller or company?<n><n>Input:This project asks you to estimate the cost of a computer without a hard drive or operating system using a spreadsheet (which shows the cost of a computer with 1 TB of hard drive and Windows 7) and the
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Long term consumption of beer can lead to all sorts of problems, it can be quite what? Choices:  A: water B: liquid C: foamy D: intoxicating E: harmful<n>Output:		 In the long term consumption of beer increases the risk of certain diseases. Choices: B: C: D: C: D: D: D: C: C: B: A: D: A: D: B: B: C: C:<n>Output: Drinking in excess can increase the risk of coronary heart disease and strokes, and also the risk of some types of cancer<n>This is bad news if your plan is to have a beer with friends tomorrow night<n><n>Input:The price of a unit of gas (liters) is given by:<n>Output:  The price of a liter in US was $0.59<n>So the price of gasoline is $0.59 per gallon<n>So the final answer was $0.30<n><n>Input:If the weather forecast is 50 degrees and sunny, and the temperature drops to 44 degrees, the chances of a snowstorm are one/50=.  What is the odds of a snowstorm?<n>Output: Only 1/50 = about<n>So one in 50 = about<n>And on a really sunny day this is unlikely by about<n><n>Input:Two people buy 8 pieces of chocolate. Based on these two examples, how many chocolate servings did each person eat each day?<n>Output: 8/50 = 1.1=20.3 chocolate servings<n>So the average amount of chocolate each person eats each day is 20.3<n>That means the total is 80.9<n>That means 80.9/2=20.3<n>That means 20/2=2.5<n>In total the final answer is 60.7<n><n>Input:A student goes walking up and down the block talking to people. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:The boy was too nervous to dance, so what was he doing progressively at the ball? Choices:  A: dance like crazy B: standing still C: wallflower D: stand still E: like dancing<n>Output:		 He was at his ball<n><n>Input: John walked along the beach to check the tide.  He then came home.  He found a jellyfish eating up all the sand. It looked very much like his dog.  How did John determine it was his pup?<n>Output: The red spot was his pup.  The purple spot was his dog.<n><n>Input: The doctor was so busy on the phone and couldn't take any more patients, that he just told the man to go home and take his wife to the hospital. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:Where might a human sit for extended periods over a bowl of water? Choices:  A: bathroom B: solar system C: coffee shop D: space shuttle E: airport<n>Output:		 If the human sits in the bathroom and water flows in through the drain, but doesn't get to the bowl, then the question is invalid.<n>The human sits in the solar system and drinks from the coffee shop sink.<n><n>Input:Suppose you had three people working on two different computers on two different computers using two different sets of keyboard, mice, and monitors. What is the probability that one of the three computers produces a virus?<n>Output:It is 5/2 if at least one of the three computers is infected with a virus, and it is 10/2 if at least three of the computers<n><n>Input:Supposing you have four people working on two computers on two computers using two different sets<n>of keyboard, mouse, and monitors. What are the chances that one of the workers will<n>make a mistake that results in five computers infected with a virus? How much<n>chance is there of at least one computer being infected?<n>Output:It depends how many machines are infected. If the number of infected computers is 5/4, 60%<n><n>Input:Supposed you have four sets of two keyboards, four sets of four mice, and four sets of two monitors.<n>Suppose a worker makes three mistakes, resulting in one computer infected with a virus.<n>Output: It is 0/5 if the virus affects all the computers at the same time, and it is 1/5<n><n>Input:Supppose a human and an owl are assigned an identical machine and computer. The owl must move<n>the machine one thousand feet over three days using a rope, a compass, and a map.<n>Output:The first day, the human has to use all the equipment to move the machine. The second day, the owl has 10 minutes to<n>walk from west to east on the map. The third day, the owl can take the rope to move the machine<n>to north, then it has 15 minutes to walk to south. The owl can only be carried<n>a distance of 1,000 feet if the ground is firm. If a piece of paper falls off the top<n>of the map while it is being moved, the animal will fall over. If it is carried<n>anywhere but through a piece of paper, then it will fall off and not be moved.<n>If at the end of day three, the owl fails at least twice, the owl dies.<n><n>Input:A person walks 30 kilometers every day to work.  Each day the person walks<n>300 meters,
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Output: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>So the final answer is 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:If I have a forgiving attitude toward someone, what do they receive? Choices:  A: redemption B: isolation C: absolution D: great relief E: feel better<n>Output:		 A<n>*A:* "You're forgiven" *B:* "Insanity does not excuse" *C:* "I forgive you" *D:* "I'm releasing you from this sin"<n>*E:* "I'm getting rid of this unwanted thing in your life"<n>So the final answer can be: A, B, D, C, E<n>So the final answer was A

It's a top division competition with teams from all over the country. In every game there are 2 teams. One team has 12 players and the other has 12 players. The rule is that each player can play 30 minutes each. In a 30-minute match, each player has the option of playing 60, 30, 20 or 10 minutes. The players make up their own time. The players can play anywhere from 5 to 20 minutes per game at any time of the game. The team that plays first has the whole team to themselves! If the first team wins, they are allowed to play a total of four other full-time teams as subs for the rest of the game. One other team is allowed to join the subs later in the game when the ball is over halfway in the opposing team's half. If the second team wins, their team has to wait for the time to expire before coming onto the field. If neither team wins, each side is allowed to play four minutes each. At half time the players are all told to come off to rest for the other team, but they all get back on in 5 minutes. Then they will be allowed to play another 15 minutes. The second half starts with the subs allowed to play 20 minutes each. At half the subs get on the field at their own pace, but the 2 remaining teams have 15 minutes apiece, to be played at the rate chosen by each of the teams. If either team scores more goals than the other, the goal differential between the two teams in the other team's half is multiplied by the goal differential between the teams in the other coach's half. The teams in the other coach’s half always take the rest of half time to decide. The teams with the fewest goals are always relegated from the league. This last year we had ten teams in the league. Most teams came from small towns. Our team was the only top team from an outer suburb.<n>Output: This is a simulation of a hypothetical league where teams win 1 game every 10 matches..<n>For example:<n>Scenario 1: The average points scored by all teams in a season is 100 points (or 40 goals).<n>For Example: The average points scored in a match is 80<n>If Scenario 1 happens, then the team with the average points scored over that season of 80 wins the title.<n>Scenario 2: In

If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Output: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>So the final answer is 30<n><n>Input:What planet is the atlantic ocean part of? Choices:  A: planet B: basin C: submarines D: earth E: pacific<n>Output:		 Planet B......C... E.....D.. pacific.....P.....earth....  earth<n>P<n>F<n>1<n>2<n>3<n>E<n><n>Input: For a million dollars, how much does Steve need to pay off his parents' mortgages?<n>Output: If he pays 3200 * 10 = 4.5 million, he has to pay off his parents'.<n><n>Input:Suppose Steve and Elizabeth both earn $100,000 a year and pay no taxes -- they are neither wealthy nor poor. Their combined income is $700,000. The annual income tax of $700,000 is $3,500, but $1,000 of it is paid by Steve: that is, Steve owes $3,500 (tax rate + $1,000 bonus) in personal income tax. Suppose he has $100,000 in a joint IRA whose earnings are taxed 25%, what is his tax rate?<n>Output: If his tax rate is =25% then his tax liability is =3,500*25%=<<3,500/>3,500<n>So his tax rate is =3/200*200 =<<3/200/>3/200 +3/200*>>>3/200+>>>3/200 =<n><n>Output: Suppose Steve and Elizabeth both earn at $100,000 a years. Every year, they pay taxes: $75 each, since $75/9 = $72.  Steve has a tax liability of $3,500; Elizabeth has no liability since she pays no taxes. With a tax rate of $72 a year, Steve pays an income tax of $3,500. (If tax rates were to be raised to $180, Steve would pay $4,500. The same would be true for Elizabeth. The tax rate for them remains at $75.)<n><n>Input:For the last 2.5 years, Steve has paid taxes of $800 each. Now what is the value of his tax liability?<n>Output: Taxable income will be $200,000, since it amounts to $800 a year. The value of his tax liability is $800<n><n>Input:1,2,3,4 are integers. What is the first step in a program that takes a sequence of numbers for each item in list to count those numbers?<n>Output:Count is the procedure used to count the numbers
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Output: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>So the final answer is 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Output: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>So the final answer is 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Let the horse avoid stepping on the bricks during turns by walking on them. Let it become increasingly frustrated as the turns become more difficult. If he still cannot get past the bricks, keep bringing them closer and closer to the horse until he can avoid stepping on them. Let the horse run on the cement after getting frustrated and walk on the asphalt towards the end of the road
